thread.title: Friends and family are mourning the loss of 16-year-old Amir Ammari
thread.title_full: Friends and family are mourning the loss of 16-year-old Amir Ammari | News Local

author: Daniel Zautsen
title: Friends and family are mourning the loss of 16-year-old Amir Ammari
text:
Amir Ammari with older brother Firas Ammari. Picture: Facebook Macarthur Friends and family are mourning the loss of 16-year-old Amir Ammari Daniel Zautsen, Macarthur Chronicle Campbelltown February 24, 2017 5:06pm
Tributes are pouring in for a 16-year-old Robert Townson High School student who died after falling from a tree at Helensburg on Wednesday.
Amir Ammari has been described as ‘one brave soldier’ by devastated family members who are now coming to terms with the loss of a beloved son and brother.
Amir fell 15m into a swimming hole when the tree branch he was swinging from at Kellys Falls in Helensburgh snapped at 1.30pm on Wednesday.
He hit his head on a submerged rock and was knocked unconscious before being dragged from the water by friends.
He was flown to Royal North Shore Hospital but succumbed to his injuries later that night.
Amir’s brother Firas Ammari expressed his grief on Facebook with a series of posts.
“I was always able to do something, always got you out of trouble and always stopped you from doing stupid shit, but now I can’t do anything I’m so sorry man, I wish I could’ve done something to stop this from happening Allah yerhamak Amir,” he said.
media_camera Artwork tribute to 16-year-old Amir Ammari. Picture: Facebook
“Rest easy Amir, you were one hell of a brother man, can’t believe you were taken from us. This still doesn’t feel real, this just feels like a big nightmare and I really want to wake up. I miss you man, you were one brave soldier. Allah Yerhamo, taken too young.”
Detective Inspector Brad Ainsworth from Wollongong Local Area Command told AAP the situation was tragic for the family and his friends.
“It’s tragic. He had his three mates who watched on, that witnessed everything — they pulled him from the water. You can only describe it as horrific, really, and I suppose, if we want to put a warning to it, watch where you swim and be aware of your surrounds.”
Suburban Islamic Association publicity officer Tamrez Khan said the local Muslim community was in mourning at the tragic loss and said the Minto Mosque would welcome members of the community over the weekend to pay their respects.
media_camera Tributes placed at Robert Townson High School for Amir. Picture: Facebook
“It’s very sad and we send our condolences out to the family,” he said.
“He was a very bright and energetic person but also he was a sober, polite and very kind person; it’s such a tragedy.”
Janazah prayer, an Islamic funeral prayer, was held at Lakemba Mosque today with the family while members of Macarthur’s Muslim community gathered for their regular Friday service where they also offered prayers for Amir.
Services to offer condolences open to Muslim and non-Muslim friends are being held tonight, Saturday and Sunday at Minto Mosque.
A paramedic who received serious leg and ankle injuries after slipping down a ravine during the rescue was flown to St George Hospital for treatment.
